raw_text:
Wilkinson to lead England
 
 Fly-half Jonny Wilkinson has been named as England's new rugby union captain for the three November Tests.
 
 The 25-year-old Newcastle star takes over from Lawrence Dallaglio, who retired from internationals in August. England's acting head coach Andy Robinson said: "He is a natural leader, holds the respect of the squad and is a formidable talent on the pitch. "And he consistently demonstrates the energy and commitment I feel is essential to be captain of England." Robinson added: "There are several players in the squad I would feel comfortable in calling upon to be England captain but for me Jonny is in every way the right player to take on this challenge. "Captaincy offers a challenging environment for any player, especially following in the footsteps of Lawrence Dallaglio and before him the World Cup captain, Martin Johnson.
 
 "But I am confident Jonny has what it takes to do an outstanding job as we look ahead towards the next Rugby World Cup in France and I look forward to working with him." Wilkinson, who has scored 817 points in 52 internationals, kicked the winning drop-goal in the final seconds of extra-time in England's 2003 Rugby World Cup triumph against Australia. But he then missed the entire 2004 Six Nations campaign while recuperating from shoulder surgery, before making his comeback for Newcastle in the Zurich Premiership in August. "It's the ambition of so many players to one day be captain of England and today I have realised a dream," he said. "I'm honoured Andy wants me to be his captain, and to follow Lawrence and Martin means a lot to me as they are inspirational men who have given so much to England rugby over many years.
 
 "Getting my first England cap against Ireland six years ago was something I'll never forget because to play for your country is very special. Taking on the captaincy is another important step in my career and I do so with immense pride." Wilkinson made his international debut in the 1998 Six Nations Championship against Ireland when he came off the bench to replace Paul Grayson.
 
 He has been a regular in the England starting line-up ever since, played in all three Lions Tests in 2001 and all but one of England's games in the 2003 World Cup. He becomes the 117th captain of England since Fred Stokes held the position in 1871. England's first autumn Test is against Canada on 13 November, followed by the visit of Tri-Nations champions South Africa a week later and then a World Cup re-match with Australia.
llama3.2:1b: Jonny Wilkinson has been named as England's new rugby union captain for the three November Tests. He replaces Lawrence Dallaglio who retired in August. Robinson praises Wilkinson's leadership qualities, energy, and commitment to be captain of England. Wilkinson is expected to take on a challenging role following in the footsteps of other England captains like Martin Johnson and Lawrence Dallaglio.
llama3.2:3b: Jonny Wilkinson has been named as England's new rugby union captain for three November Tests, replacing Lawrence Dallaglio. He will lead the team in all three matches, including against Canada on 13 November.
gemma2:2b:
Jonny Wilkinson has been named captain for England's three November Tests.  He will follow in the footsteps of Lawrence Dallaglio and Martin Johnson. 
Wilkinson made his international debut in 1998 and is known for scoring the winning drop-goal during England's 2003 Rugby World Cup victory.  He expresses pride in taking on this challenge, following in the footsteps of iconic captains. 
The first November Test will be against Canada on November 13th.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Jonny Wilkinson has been named as England’s new rugby union captain for three consecutive November Tests after Lawrence Dallaglio was suspended from his role due to a health issue. Wilkinson is an experienced fly-half who has scored 817 points in 52 internationals and kicked the winning drop-goal in the final seconds of extra-time against England in the 2003 Rugby World Cup, making him an ideal candidate for this leadership position.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Jonny Wilkinson named new England rugby union captain for three November Tests, succeeding Lawrence Dallaglio. Wilkinson previously led the team in international matches; he becomes 117th England captain since Fred Stokes. The Test series includes Canada, South Africa, and a World Cup rematch with Australia.

Robinson, acting head coach, praised Wilkinson's leadership skills and natural talent. Wilkinson scored 817 points in 52 internationals and has played in various key matches including the 2003 World Cup final. The first autumn Test is against Canada on 13 November, followed by South Africa and a rematch with Australia.

For him to be captain of England means a lot to me as they are inspirational men who have given so much to England rugby over many years." deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Jonny Wilkinson leading England as rugby union captain. Let me read through it carefully.

Alright, first sentence says Wilkin's being named captain for the England rugby union team on November 3rd. He replaces Lawrence Dallaglio, who retired in August. So I should note his age (25), position (cup vice-captain), and the new role as captain.

Next, Andy Robinson is the acting coach, talking about Wilkin being a leader with respect and energy. That's important to mention because it gives context on why he was chosen. He added that there are several players suitable for captaincy, especially since Dallaglio and Johnson were previous captains.

Then, Wilkin made his first caps in 1998 Six Nations when he came off the bench against Ireland. He's been in England's starting lineup ever since. In the 2003 World Cup, he scored 817 points, making a winning drop-goal for their triumph over Australia.

He also mentioned that getting his first cap against Ireland was special because it's such an honor to play for your country. Taking on the captaincy is another big step in his career, and he feels lucky that Andy wants him to be England's captain.

Wilkin also acknowledged the ambition of so many players wanting to become captains and mentions Lawrence Dallaglio and Martin Johnson as influential figures. He's inspired by their bravery and dedication.

In summary, I need to capture his leadership qualities, previous role, current stats, upcoming matches, and the significance of his status as a captain.
</think>

Jonny Wilkinson is being appointed as England's rugby union captain for the 2003 Rugby World Cup against Australia. He replaces Lawrence Dallaglio with whom he shares the responsibility. Wilkin, 25, has been in England since 1998 and has led him to multiple success, including scoring 817 points in 52 international caps, making a memorable drop-goal in their 2003 World Cup win over Australia. He is inspired by Lawrence Dallaglio and Martin Johnson, two influential captains, who have paved the way for England's strong performance. As captain, he looks forward to leading England towards future successes, including the upcoming World Cup against Ireland and South Africa.
tinyllama:1.1b: Ahead of England's three November tests against Canada, Newcastle Fly-half Jonny Wilkinson becomes the 117th captain in English rugby union history, following in the footsteps of former captain Lawrence Dallaglio and ahead of the World Cup in France. The 25-year-old Newcastle star is a natural leader who consistently demonstrates energy and commitment to capturing England's leadership role. He will lead the team during the upcoming matches against Canada, with the visit of South Africa a week later, followed by a re-match against Australia in the World Cup. Wilkinson has amassed 817 points in 52 internationals and kicking the winning drop-goal in England's final match for the 2003 World Cup.

It mentions that the decision was made after considering various candidates, including Lawrence Dallaglio, who retired from international rugby in August. The new captain will take charge during three November Tests, starting with Canada.

Acting head coach Andy Robinson praised Wilkinson's leadership, talent, and commitment. Wilkinson, who famously kicked the winning drop-goal in England's 2003 World Cup victory, missed the 2004 Six Nations due to injury but recently returned to play. He expressed his honor at being chosen, following in the footsteps of inspirational captains. Wilkinson, who debuted in 1998, has been a key player for England and the British & Irish Lions. He takes over from Martin Johnson, showing his natural leadership skills, energy, and commitment. Despite facing challenges like following in the footsteps of inspirational men and missing several tournaments due to injury, Wilkinson is confident he can excel as England's captain for future Rugby World Cup events.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
Jonny Wilkinson, a 25-year-old fly-half from Newcastle, has been appointed as England's new rugby union captain for the upcoming November Tests, replacing Lawrence Dallaglio who retired from international play in August. Andy Robinson, acting head coach, praised Wilkinson for his natural leadership, respect within the squad, and on-field talent. The decision came after careful consideration of several potential candidates, with Robinson confident that Wilkinson possesses the necessary qualities to excel in this role, especially considering his predecessors' significant contributions to England rugby.

Wilkinson, who has scored 817 points in 52 international appearances and kicked the winning drop-goal in the 2003 Rugby World Cup final against Australia, expressed immense pride in this honor, recognizing it as a culmination of years of dedication. He made his debut against Ireland in 1998 and has since been a consistent fixture in England's starting line-up, participating in various Rugby World Cup matches and Lions Tests.

England's autumn Test schedule includes games against Canada (November 13), South Africa (November 20), and Australia (a rematch from the 2003 World Cup). As the 117th captain of England since Fred Stokes held the position in 1871, Wilkinson is ready to take on this challenging role as they gear up for the Rugby World Cup in France.
